Don’t believe it, Zachvac:
“Any statement given freely and voluntarily without any compelling influences is, of course, admissible in evidence. . . . Volunteered statements of any kind are not barred by the Fifth Amendment.” Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 478 (1966)
The Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination prohibits your being compelled to give testimonial evidence against yourself. (Like the baseball players who were compelled by subpoena to appear and testify before Congress). The right has absolutely no application to firearms transaction forms. When you go purchase a gun no one forces you to fill out the forms. Oh, you can’t walk out with the gun unless you do, but it is your choice whether to buy the gun or not. You can always refuse to fill out the forms and walk away without a gun. To argue otherwise would permit convicted felons to claim they have a right to use a fake ID to get around the background check (which is currently a felony offense punished by up to 10 years in VA), since using their real name would compel them to incriminate themselves. Thankfully, no court has yet succumbed to such illogic.
The right recognized in the Second Amendment is no more absolute that the “right of the people” in the 1st. and 4th. Amendments. None of these rights are absolute, and they are all subject to some rational limitation (like the ban on possession by convicted felons).

No problem, Zachvac. I have actually heard someone argue that a requirement of filling out a firearms transaction form forces convicted felons to incriminate themselves when they go buy a gun (by an attorney, no less, which once again proves that lack of intelligence is no bar to success in the profession). 
I believe that the entire “collective right” theory is a sham. I believe that some of my gun control friends know in their hearts they are unable to debunk the overwhelming historical evidence which proves the Second Amendment was intended to recognize an individual right. I believe the reason why they are unwilling to admit that the right is individual is because they fear doing so will unleash a torrent of litigation that will abolish every law which regulates the possession of firearms. I want to again say that recognition of an individual RKBA will not have this doomsday effect. There are laws, like the ban on possession by felons, which will justly survive an individual right interpretation. I just wish I could get some of my more ardent (and unabashedly liberal) civil libertarian friends to give the Second Amendment a fair shake. They will rant and rave all day long about governmental abuse of other civil liberties. Yet, whenever the RKBA is mentioned, these staunch defenders of constitutional liberty will blanch and fall silent. Such conduct in my opinion reflects the triumph of the dictates of political correctness over reason.
Well, I for one do not believe that the Second Amendment should be treated like it is the red headed step child of the Constitution—that it must be kept locked up in the restrictive basement which some legislators reserve to bury rights they disagree with or for hiding those which they fear may frighten the more enlightened guest who visits us from overseas; where they know that another government’s long deprivation of the RKBA has caused its more timid subjects to become accustomed to its absence. So, my gun control friends, I say the time has come. It’s time to let her come out of the windowless basement you have sought to regulate her to and let her enjoy the sunlight we reserve for all our constitutional liberties. It’s time to stop the Orwellian double-think you force yourselves to engage in when you seek to cut and paste the Second Amendment out of our body of liberties. It’s time to recognize the reality that the right is individual and move on to discuss what restrictions should or would survive a constitutional challenge. In doing so you have nothing to fear but fear itself.
